titleStmt.title: New propositions from His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, sent to the Kings most Excellent Majesty: with his reasons, why he did not conduct His Majesty to White-Hall, when His Excellency marched through the city. As also, the time when His Majesty shall come, and upon what tearmes and conditions. And the substance of the armies new proposals, to be signed by King and Parliament.
titleStmt.author: Fairfax, Thomas Fairfax, Baron, 1612-1671.

titleStmt.title: New propositions from His Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, sent to the Kings most Excellent Majesty: with his reasons, why he did not conduct His Majesty to White-Hall, when His Excellency marched through the city. As also, the time when His Majesty shall come, and upon what tearmes and conditions. And the substance of the armies new proposals, to be signed by King and Parliament.
titleStmt.author: Fairfax, Thomas Fairfax, Baron, 1612-1671.
England and Wales. Army. Council.

publicationStmt.publisher: Printed at Oxford by Leonard Brown, and reprinted at London for Robert Williams,

notesStmt.note: Dated and signed at end: At the head quarters at Kingston upon Thames, Aug. 18. 1647. By the appointment of his Excellency, and the Generall Councell of his army. Signed, Iohn Rushworth, Secr.
The imprint is false; "There never was a Leonard Brown at Oxford, and the Proposals were never printed there"--Madan.
With a title-page woodcut captioned: Carolus Rex. Generall Fairfax.
Annotation on Thomason copy: between 'New' and 'propositions': "false"; "Aug: 26".
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: NEW PROPOSITIONS From His Excellency Sir THOMAS FAIRFAX, SENT TO The Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maje≈øty: With His Rea≈øons, why He did not conduct His Maje≈øty to White-Hall. when His Excellency marched through the City. As al≈øo, the time wren His Maje≈øty ≈øhall come, and upon what tearmes and conditions. And the ≈øub≈øtance of the Armies new Propo≈øals, to be ≈øigned by King and Parliament.

figure.figDesc: depiction of King Charles I and General Fairfax
figure.head: C ‚Ä¢ ROLUS R ‚Ä¢ X. GENERALL FAIRFAX.

div.p: Printed at Oxford by Leonard Brown, and Reprinted at London for Robert Williams, Anno Dom. 1647. Aug. :26:

div.head: Certain new Propo≈øals from his Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax, concerning the Kings mo≈øt Excellent Maie≈øty.
div.p:
HIs Excellency Sir Thomas Fairfax having a tender and deepe ≈øen≈øe of ≈øeverall difficulties and dangers which were like to en≈øue, and of the evill and treacherous dealings of the publike Enemies to the Peace of this Syon, again≈øt the Parliament, Army, and Kingdomes peace and welfare; having a long time ≈øought and endeavoured to breake tho≈øe ≈øilver Cords of Amity, which hath been ≈øo unanimou≈øly knit together, betwixt the hearts of our renowned Generall, and the whole Kingdome; and finding that all their wicked ≈øtratagems, and Hell-bred Devices could not take effect, they began to bethinke them≈øelves of a new Project (which indeed was a mo≈øt
horrid and de≈øperate one) and that was their great activene≈ø≈øe in ≈øending and di≈øpier≈øing of their ≈øeverall Agents throughout many Counties within this Kingdome; to the end, that they might u≈øe their utmo≈øt endeavours to ≈øeduce the People, and to make his Excellency and the Army odious unto them, by defaming their ju≈øt and honourable Endeavours, with mo≈øt fal≈øe and ≈øcandalous a≈øper≈øions, and all under this Mask and Pretence, that the Generall and Army ≈øought their own private ends, more then the good & welfare of this langui≈øhing Kingdom, with many more ≈øuch like untruths and fal≈øe a≈øper≈øions, and that there was a de≈øign in hand for bringing his Maje≈øty to London, and re≈øtoring of the Kingdom to their ju≈øt rights and liberties.
All which delu≈øions could not prevaile to withdraw the hearts of the People from his Excellency, but were re≈øolved to live and dye with him in the Armies ju≈øt Cau≈øe and Engagement, &c.

His Excellency, and the Councell of the Army, having ≈øeriou≈øly con≈øidered the wicked practi≈øes & evill de≈øignes of the≈øe men, and the great ruine that might befall this Kingdome, if not timely prevented, thought requi≈øite (for ≈øatisfaction of the whole Kingdom) to Declare as followeth, and to repre≈øent the≈øe en≈øuing Propo≈øals to the view of the whole world, viz. I. THat when (by the ble≈ø≈øing of God) all things were compo≈øed & the Kingdom reduced to a peaceable condition, there were cro≈ø≈øe workings by a prevalent party, roob≈øtruct and pervert ju≈øtice, and oppre≈ø≈øe the peaceable and well affected people of the Kingdome and by holding forth pretences of Uniformity, oppre≈ø≈øed the people, and to further their
de≈øignes rai≈øed jealou≈øies, and to further their de≈øignes got a power into their hands of a publike influence, whereby they had the advantage to rai≈øe a new warre and make di≈øturbances in the Common wealth, and the impeached Members continued about London very active therein and the new Militia joyned with them in ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ ≈øting of Reformadoes, & others, by which meanes the Speakers and many fa ‚Ä¢ thfull Members of b ‚Ä¢ th Hou≈øes were forced away, after which ≈øome Members remaining cho≈øe new Speakers, that they might act according to their own ends and that the proceedings & votes of the major part of them during the ab≈øence of the Speaker, intended to the carrying on of a trea≈øonable Engagement.

After which, all of them concentring (as in other things, ≈øo e≈øpecially) in this, viz. To have the King brought up to London without delay, or any neerer approach of the Army. To which his Excellency propounds, as followeth:
I. That had the King come up to Londen (as they have ≈øo oft de≈øired and attempted) it is apparent they intended and would have made u≈øe of it, rather to lay the ≈øtronger foundations of a new war, then any way to ≈øettle thereby a ≈øafe and well-grounded Peace.
II. And ≈øince they could not rationally expect ≈øo ca≈øie an obtaining of the Kings Per≈øon to London, upon any pretence what≈øoever, yet it is evident, that they could intend nothing thereby, but a more plaudible pretence and foundation of quarrell again≈øt this Army, whereby to engage or incline to their a≈ø≈øi≈øtancethe Kings Party, and ≈øuch others who might bee catcht with the apprehen≈øion thereof, as a ≈øpeedy way to Peace (the thing ≈øo generally longed for) and by ≈øuch a≈ø≈øi≈øtance
gained, the better to ruine this Army, and tho≈øe faithfull Members of Parliament who retired to it.
III. Thirdly, For our parts wee ≈øhall reioyce as much as any, to ≈øee the King brought backe, to his Parliament, and that not ≈øo much in place, as in affection and agreement, on ≈øuch ≈øound terms and grounds as may render both him and the Kingdom, ≈øafe, quiet, and happy, and ≈øhall be as ready as any to bring his Maje≈øty to London, when his being there may be likely to produce (not greater Di≈øturbances or Di≈øtractions, but a Peace indeed, and that ≈øuch as may not be ≈øhaped and moulded only to the private advantages of a particular party or faction, but bottom'd chiefly on grounds of common and publike ≈øafety.
IV. That if (without regard to the≈øe con≈øiderations) we would have brought his Maje≈øty with us to London in our late advance thither (which our Enemies could not hinder or prejudice us in) we had no cau≈øe to doubt, but (as to men) wee might have had all the advantages, which our Adver≈øaries promi≈øed to them≈øelves thereby, added to the ≈øtrength &
intre≈øt of the Army, and have inverted the di≈øadvantages upon them that they intended again≈øt vs thereby, ≈øo as his Maje≈øties coming to London might have beene much to their preiudice and our advantage, if we had regarded only our own particulars.
V. That we have not minded nor bin acting our own workes and intere≈øts, but the kingdomes, and every hone≈øt mans in it.
For all which, it is propounded and de≈øired, that the chiefe Actors of the late De≈øigne may forthwith bee brought to tryall; and it is further declared, as followeth, viz.

That if any of tho≈øe Members, who during the ab≈øence of the ≈øpeakers and the re≈øt of the Members of both Hou≈øes (forced away by the tumultuous violence afore≈øaid) did ≈øit and Vote in the pretended Hou≈øes then continuing at We≈øtmin≈øter ≈øhall hereafter intrude them≈øelves to ≈øit in Parliament (before they ≈øhall have given ≈øatisfaction to the re≈øpective Hou≈øes, wherefore they are concerning the grounds of their ≈øaid ≈øitting at We≈øtmin≈øter, during the ab≈øence of the ≈øaid ≈øpeakers, and ≈øhall have acquited them≈øelves by ≈øufficient evidence, that they did not procure or give their con≈øent unto any of tho≈øe pretended Votes, Orders, or Ordinances tending to the rai≈øing, and levying of a Warre (as is be ‚Ä¢ ore declared) or for the King ‚Ä¢ coming forthwith to London) we cannot
any longer ≈øuffer the ≈øame, but ≈øhall doe that Right to the ≈øpeakers, and Members of both Hou≈øes who were driven away to us, and to our ≈øelves with them, (all whom the ≈øaid other Members have indeavoured in an ho≈øtile manner, mo≈øt unju≈øtly to de≈øtroy,) and al≈øo to the Kingdome, which the endeavoured to imbroyle in a new Warre,) as to take ≈øome ≈øpeedy, and effectuall cour≈øe whereby to re≈øtraine them, from being their own, and ours, and the Kingdomes Judges in tho≈øe things wherein they have made them≈øelves parties, by this meanes to make way that both they, and others that are guilty, and parties to the afore≈øaid trea≈øonable, and dectructive practi≈øes, and proceedings again≈øt the Freedome of Parliament, and peace of the Kingdome may be brought to condigne puni≈øhment (and and that at a Judgement of a Free Parliament, con≈øi≈øting (duly, and pro perly) of ≈øuch Members of both Hou≈øes re≈øpectively, who ≈øtand cleare from ≈øuch apparent, and trea≈øonable breach of their tru≈øt, as is before expre≈ø≈øed.

closer.dateline: At the head quarters at Kingston upon Thames, Aug. 18. 1647.
closer.signed: By the appointment of his Excellency, and the Generall Councell of his Army. Signed, Iohn Ru≈øhworth, Secr.

postscript.p: The Army are perfecting of a modell by way of Propo≈øitions to be confirmed by King and Parliament for ≈øetling a firme Peace, they are the ≈øub≈øtance of their former Propo≈øitions.
